comment.body: Added coverage for both incremental and non-incremental.

pull_request.title: Use an immutable workspace for all non-incremental transforms
pull_request.body:
Previously project-bound transforms were always executed in a mutable, project-bound workspace, even when they were non-incremental. By allocating immutable workspaces for non-incremental work we get to reuse their outputs locally more often without having to hit the build cache.

A consequence of this change is that running `clean` does not remove the outputs of non-incremental project-bound transforms anymore. Only the outputs of incremental transforms will be stored in `$buildDir/.transforms`.

Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/26694

pull_request.title: Use an immutable workspace for all non-incremental transforms
pull_request.body:
Previously project-bound transforms were always executed in a mutable, project-bound workspace, even when they were non-incremental. By allocating immutable workspaces for non-incremental work we get to reuse their outputs locally more often without having to hit the build cache.

A consequence of this change is that running `clean` does not remove the outputs of non-incremental project-bound transforms anymore. Only the outputs of incremental transforms will be stored in `$buildDir/.transforms`.

Fixes https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/26694

commits.message: Run test for both incremental and non-incremental scenarios

issue.title: Gradle 3.4.1 unable to build with FileNotFoundExcepiton(Operation not permitted)
issue.body:
Hi All,

I been trying to clean build my gradle project with gradle wrapper 3.4.1 however was hitting the FileNotFoundException below

java.io.FileNotFoundException: /home/cheehoo/.gradle/caches/3.4.1/scripts-remapped/build_e2k02sjfohvdnii4nsaft7itr/c2d3oidpxg1t1bruezd0p3v75/proje7d8605dddf6ee8d441e8a198843b754/classes/build_e2k02sjfohvdnii4nsaft7itr$_run_closure11$_closure23$_closure25$_closure28$_closure29$_closure31.class (Operation not permitted )

I did try to find the file in the caches/3.4.1/script-remapped and it does not exist and i also tried to delete the cache folder however it still display the same errors. Anyone of encounter such errors before ?  


### Expected Behavior
Gradle should be able to build successfully without any errors

### Current Behavior
When building with gradle >=3.0(currently i am using 3.4.1 however i did tried few version and version 2.x is working fine) it present me with error FileNotFoundException as indicated above 

### Context
This issue have blocked me to build using gradle 3.4.1 

### Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
./gradlew clean build

### Your Environment
CentOS release 6.7 on virtual box 4.3.20

------------------------------------------------------------
Gradle 3.4.1
------------------------------------------------------------

Build time:   2017-03-03 19:45:41 UTC
Revision:     9eb76efdd3d034dc506c719dac2955efb5ff9a93

Groovy:       2.4.7
Ant:          Apache Ant(TM) version 1.9.6 compiled on June 29 2015
JVM:          1.7.0_79 (Oracle Corporation 24.79-b02)
OS:           Linux 2.6.32-573.el6.x86_64 amd64

comment.body:
Run Android Studio as an Administrator

sudo /Applications/Android\ Studio.app/Contents/MacOS/studio

requested_teams.description: BT Developer Relations and Education Team

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -211,6 +212,23 @@ public interface NamedDomainObjectCollection<T> extends DomainObjectCollection<T
     @Override
     <S extends T> NamedDomainObjectCollection<S> withType(Class<S> type);
 
+    /**
+     * Returns a collection containing the objects with names matching the provided filter.
+     * The returned collection is live, so that when matching objects are added to this collection,
+     * they are also visible in the filtered collection.
+     * This method will NOT cause any pending objects in this container to be realized.
+     *
+     * @param nameFilter The specification to test names against.
+     * @return The collection of objects with names satisfying the filter. Returns an empty collection if there are no such objects in this collection.
+     *
+     * @since 8.5
+     */
+    @Incubating
+    default NamedDomainObjectCollection<T> named(Spec<String> nameFilter) {
+        // default implementation is a workaround for plugins having their own custom collection implementation, based on an older interface (i.e. missing an implementation for this method)
+        throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Method not implemented in " + GeneratedSubclasses.unpack(this.getClass()).getName()); // todo: check out what it prints for KGP
comment.body:
💅 Nitpicking but the rationale is that the displayed type is not necessarily the one where the implementation should go. It could be in a parent class.
```suggestion
        throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Method not implemented by " + GeneratedSubclasses.unpack(this.getClass()).getName()); // todo: check out what it prints for KGP
```

@@ -97,4 +97,257 @@ class NamedDomainObjectContainerIntegrationTest extends AbstractDomainObjectCont
         expect:
         succeeds "help"
     }
+
+    def "name based filtering"() {
+        buildFile << """
+            testContainer.named({ it.endsWith("foo") }).all { element ->
+                assert element.name in ['foo', 'barfoo']
+            }
+
+            testContainer.register("foo")
+            testContainer.register("bar")
+            testContainer.register("foobar")
+            testContainer.register("barfoo")
+        """
+        expect:
+        succeeds "help"
+    }
+
+    def "custom collection not implementing named method triggers useful error message"() {
+        buildFile << """
+            objects.newInstance(MyNamedDomainObjectCollection).named { !it.isEmpty() }
comment.body: 💅 I would make that a unit test with the custom type part of the test source set. This would make it easier on us when changing the `NamedDomainObjectCollection` type by making test compilation fail early, find usages work in the IDE instead of having to wait for that integration test to run.

comment.body:
💅 There is a typo in word `methog`

💭 Is it possible to add IntelliJ's `Contract` annotation that expresses this nullability contract? IIUC, they support conditionals like `null -> null` and `non-null -> non-null` for parameter-return-value relationship.
We don't have to do this in this PR, but your comment triggered this idea.

+/*
+ * Copyright 2023 the original author or authors.

+ * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
+ * you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
+ * You may obtain a copy of the License at

+/**
+ * Configuration input tracking implementation.
+ * The build configuration may be influenced by various "environmental" inputs.
+ * For example, build logic may read files or access environment variables.
+ * Knowing these inputs is important for configuration caching to understand if the cache has to be invalidated when the value of the system property changes.
+ * It can also be used to determine undeclared task inputs, and the likes.
+ */
+@NonNullApi

commits.message:
Canonicalize "." and ".." segments in RelativePaths

Fixes #5748

As documented in #5748, Sync and Copy tasks can have buggy
behaviors (such as deleting copied files) when RelativePath objects
refer to the same path but consist of a different list of segments.
This can happen in particular when "." and ".." are used in path
segments.

Avoid this situation by canonicalizing RelativePaths as they are
created, so that "." is not used and ".." only appears at the
beginning of a path.

Signed-off-by: Alex Landau <alandau@cs.stanford.edu>
